title: Large Scale Visual Geo-Localization of Images in Mountainous Terrain

author: Georges Baatz, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zürich
chairman: Michal Irani, Weizmann Institute of Science
Andrea Vedaldi, Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford

segmentation: This is joint work with Olivia Silva have incurs a ranmar qualifies.
So in recent years, interest in geotagging images has ever been increasing.
On one hand, we have GPS capable hardware like smartphones, standalone GPS loggers or even consumer cameras with built-in GPS receivers are entering the market.
On the software side, you can for example plot the places of your holiday picture so you know where where you have been.
Google is using user pictures to extend their Google Street View where their cars can drive.
And photo sharing sites are using the GPS tag to geographically organize the pictures.
So this naturally raises the question, would it be nice if you could do the same thing to older pictures?
Here, of course.
All these fancy GPS hardware can't help because, well, it's after the fact.
So we have to use what's in the image itself.
Other applications for that could be in intelligence or maybe Planetary Rovers.
So there are already a lot of local logic localization systems, but they are mostly designed to work in cities or to work with.
Image pictures taken from image sharing sites, so they are naturally clustered around tourist sites and we would like to extend this to cover nature as well.
And here we are facing a bit of a problem because the traditional touch based features like Sift and Surf don't work so well.
So in our example here you can see that there aren't that many features to start with, and if you look closely, you see that most of the correspondences are actually wrong.
The reason for that is that outdoors the appearance of natural landscapes changes a lot according to time of day and seasons.
Another thing is that there is not very dense coverage of pictures.
All over the world we could maybe consider satellite images, but the problem here is that there is a huge, very huge baseline, so that makes matching even more difficult.
So what we have decided to do is to use instead the horizon because that is extremely stable over very long time spans.
Verizon has already been used for very successfully for related applications, but this is the first time that we're using it for really large scale localization.
So this is an overview of our pipeline.
It follows pretty much the standard approach.

For the query image, however, this problem is far from trivial, so one of the tricks we use is we apply devising based on the Dark Channel prior to improve contrast.

We also use the fact that usually there is no ground above Sky, So what that means is that for each image column we only need to find one point below which everything is ground and above which everything is Sky.
This allows us to use dynamic programming approach, which is potentially a lot faster than fully generic graph cut.
We still use the same kind of.

Based on a Gaussian mixture model, an powers class that encouraged the cut of the segmentation to be orthogonal to the local gradient.

OK.
So once we have the horizon.
We use a sliding window to cut it into smaller curvelets and then each of these curvelets is first smooth than subsampled.
Then we subtract the mean and divided by the width to make a translation and scale invariant.
The numbers we obtain here are our features.
And then each each of these components is quantized separately to give us visual word.
So the standard feature word, standard bag of words approach represents an image in terms of a histogram, where for every visual word.
We count how often does this this visual word occur in the image.
So if you have two such histograms, we can look at all the differences, sum them up and this gives us a measure.
Of how different the two histograms are.
Two images are.
And this approach makes perfect sense if you expect it to images to be equal.
That is, however for us, not the case.
We are comparing perspective views with limited field of view to full panoramas.
So the histograms are going to look more like this.
So one of the images has a lot more features there are going to be a lot of differences.
And actually the distance measure will consist mostly of some irrelevant data that's coming from features that were behind the camera.
So we change the dissimilarity measure like so.
It's based on a 1 sided difference where we only penalize cases where the query image.

Alright, we further improve.
The voting stage by incorporating a rough kind of geometric verification, so the triangle up here.

If, on the other hand, the directions are not consistent, then we get through different votes, so the score is spread out among multiple candidates and none of them gets really high score.
